comments.html: I've also written a short post regarding that 1000v that gets into taking about the VEM and VSM... http://routerjockey.com/2011/02/23/introduction-to-the-nexus-1000v/
comments.name: tonhe

comments.html: Good post, as usual Ivan. I also liked tonhe's write-up - good one dude.
comments.name: Bala V

comments.html:
Ivan, nice article. The latest release of the 1000v supports QoS weighted fair queueing...

Cheers
comments.name: david

comments.html:
Hi Ivan,
I was hoping you would correct your article above, when referencing the VM-FEX. It utilizes VN-Tag(802.1qbh) not VN-Link, which is a marketing term that encompases vNICs, FI, N2K, FEX's and N1k.
VM-FEX and Adapter FEX(vNIC aka Palo card) all use the 802.1qbh.
comments.name: eric trolan

comments.html: Where exactly do you think I made a mistake?
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: No. VEM communicates with NX-OS, which means that VEM has an independent control plane, not NX-OS resident in the adjacent Nexus switch.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: VM-FEX technology used with combining n5k wich do use NX-OS. In other words VM-FEX does have the NX-OS-based control plane, isn't it?
comments.name: Дмитрий
